journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

contrib-group.aff: Faculdade de Engenharia, Universidade do Porto, Portugal

author-notes.corresp: João Falcão Carneiro, IDMEC, Faculdade de Engenharia, Universidade do Porto, Rua Dr. Roberto Frias, 4200-465 Porto, Portugal. Email: jpbrfc@fe.up.pt

abstract.p: Micro motion tasks can be found in a wide set of applications, ranging from the assembly of small parts in the semiconductor industry to assisted surgery in medicine. Conventional actuation systems for these types of task are based on the existence of electromagnetic fields (servomotors) or on the existence of some kind of material shape alteration (piezoelectric actuators). Driven by the intrinsic advantages presented by pneumatic systems, such as low cost, the absence of heat or magnetic field generation and a wide range of operation, this article presents a different approach, based on the use of commonly available industrial servopneumatic components. Experimental results show that it is possible to correctly follow 5 µm step references within a 280 mm stroke, without any controller retuning and with mass load changes from 2.69 to 13.1 kg.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: There is an increased need in industry for accurate motion control in the range of micro and nano-metre movements. Typical applications are the assembly of small parts in the semiconductor industry1 and actuation systems that underpin micro manufacturing.2 There are also some interesting applications in medicine that require high-accuracy movements, for example, robotic needle insertion in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) environments.3,4
Conventional actuation systems for micro movements are based on:

list-item.p: the existence of electromagnetic fields, as in for instance DC servomotors or stepper motors;
on the existence of induced strain on different types of materials, like, for example, lead zirconate titanate (PZT)-based piezoelectric actuators or shape memory alloys (SMAs).2,5

sec.p: There are several important characteristics that determine the choice of a micro motion device, including motion error and range, speed of response, force capabilities and the generation of heat and magnetic fields. Regarding the first four features, DC servomotors and stepper motors are undoubtedly the highest performing systems. In fact, these actuators have large motion ranges while still achieving micrometre and sub-micrometre positioning errors. They can also drive loads of several hundreds or thousands Newtons at medium velocities (1 to 2 m/s). There are, however, some drawbacks in this solution: the inherent heat and magnetic field generated do not allow its use in environments like MRI and, furthermore, conventional electrical motor solutions are bulky and therefore cannot be used when small components are required. Piezoelectric actuators, on the other hand, do not generate any magnetic or heat fields and can achieve sub-nanometre positioning errors. They also present a high speed of response. However, they exhibit a highly non-linear behaviour, their force capabilities are quite low (two orders of magnitude smaller) and the motion range is reduced to approximately 100 µm.6 SMAs are another very promising way to achieve very compact and lightweight robots5 and actuators7 having a very large force/torque-to-weight ratio. Along with PZT actuators, SMAs provide very accurate motion solutions for small working ranges.

There are several solutions to improve the working range of PZT and SMA-based devices. For instance, it is possible to stack several PZT layers together,8 or to arrange the PZT molecules in an inchworm configuration9 or to build an ultrasonic motor.10 However, the stacking option is limited by the position error generated at the end of the stack and the other two use a friction-based motion principle that limits the available payload. Another approach is to attach a small (or micro) manipulator at the end of a conventional large (macro) manipulator. These types of system, often known as macro–micro systems, can provide high-precision motion local operation and retain the versatility, speed and workspace of a larger robot.2,11,12 A very interesting study using this approach was presented in Chiang et al.13 where a pneumatic–piezoelectric hybrid actuator was developed. The pneumatic actuator performed the macro tasks, enabling high speed, long-range movements, while the piezo actuator role was to ensure fine positioning. When using only the pneumatic actuator, a steady state error of 4 µm was achieved in different step responses. When using both actuators, the positioning error became limited by the encoder resolution, 0.1 µm. Although these are excellent experimental results, no analysis was made as to the controller robustness as a function of parameter variations, i.e. when the payload varies. This is a crucial point since in common positioning tasks, like pick-and-place operations, the load may widely vary.

The present study also uses compressed air as the energy source. Pneumatic systems can be used in clean environments, have a high power-to-weight ratio and possess some important advantages such as the delivery of large amounts of power without generating significant heat or magnetic fields. These features make them potentially suited for specific applications like wafer positioning devices1 or robotic surgery in MRI environments.3,4 However, the difficulty in modelling and controlling pneumatic actuators has conventionally ruled out their use when complex motion tasks are needed. Furthermore, as shown in Brun et al.14 and Carneiro and Almeida15 undesired oscillations may arise if the pneumatic force dynamics are unobservable. Nevertheless, a recent state-of-the-art study performed by De Volder and Reynaerts16 showed that piston-type pneumatic actuators have some advantageous features when compared with conventional micro actuation devices. One such features is the power density that may reach values 105 higher than for PZT-based actuators.16 This was one of the motivations that led to the development of a micro pneumatic actuator with integrated position sensor by De Volder et al.17 In their work, a 12 mm stroke pneumatic actuator, capable of achieving 1 N at 1.5 MPa, was able to follow 3 mm length staircases, having 250 µm steps, with errors between 20 and 40 µm. The use of micro pneumatic and hydraulic piston actuators fabrication and control is a developing field of investigation for which a complete up to date review can be found in De Volder and Reynaerts.16

Most of the research on the control of pneumatic systems has been done using the more conventional macro components. Very different control strategies, ranging from classical proportional–integral–derivative (PID)18 to fuzzy logic19 have been used to handle the challenges associated with the use of servopneumatic systems. One of the most commonly used control strategies is state feedback. This was the technique followed by Ning and Bone20 where positioning errors of approximately 10 µm, even with high payload variations, were obtained. Although these are very good results achieved with standard pneumatic components, the positioning error varies with the piston position and, moreover, the technique Ning and Bone20 used appears to be extremely dependent on experimental non-procedural techniques. State feedback can also be found in the control of a 32 mm piston diameter, 400 mm stroke conventional actuator in a study by Xiang and Wikander.21 Excellent experimental results in positioning tasks were reported (steady state errors below 5 µm, the position transducer resolution) but no robustness tests were provided, i.e. regarding payload variations. Furthermore, the control technique was highly dependent on the applied model, making its application to other systems rather difficult.

Another approach is to use adaptive control techniques. For instance, Richardson et al.22 controlled a pneumatic cylinder using a state feedback controller whose parameters were determined online, based on the real-time estimation of the model parameters. Experimental results on positioning tasks indicated steady state errors below 10% of the cylinder stroke.

In order to cope with the high uncertainty of pneumatic system modelling, several studies have used a variable structure controller (VSC).23 For instance, Drakunov et al.24 developed an interesting control architecture that integrated different techniques for the mechanical and pressure dynamics control: a VSC controller was used for the pressure dynamics and a non-linear state feedback controller was used for the mechanical dynamics. Other studies using VSC controllers were developed by Pandian et al.25 and by Richer and Hurmuzlu.26 It is also possible to find applications of high-order sliding mode controllers27 in pneumatics, for example, in the study developed by Smaoui et al.28

The costs associated with servovalves can be reduced by using less expensive on/off valves.29–31 In Varseveld and Bone30 this approach was applied to a pneumatic system comprising a double-acting cylinder and two on/off valves with a 5 ms switching time. The control law was a PID type with friction compensation. The reported experimental results are very interesting since that even with a sixfold mass variation the positioning error was below 0.21 mm. Reina et al. 31 enhanced one of the strategies proposed in Varseveld and Bone30 and tested it on a vertically mounted pneumatic actuator. Although faster valves were used (a 2 ms switching time) the obtained results were worse than those obtained in Varseveld and Bone30, namely a maximum positioning error of approximately 1.4 mm was obtained. Force control of pneumatic cylinders using on/off valves has also been addressed by Sellier et al.32

A different approach was presented by Kagawa et al.1 where an air bearing pneumatic actuator positioning system was developed for the positioning of wafers under no magnetic fields and vacuum operating conditions. Since friction effects are negligible, excellent positioning results (±2 µm) were obtained. This system required, however, high development and operating costs.

In most of the described studies, positioning errors of several hundreds of micrometres are obtained. Moreover, these errors are dependent on the value of the payload and on the position set-point. The present work presents a servopneumatic device that achieves innovative results: namely a positioning error below 5 µm (the digital encoder resolution) anywhere within a stroke of 280 mm, with payloads varying between 2.69 and 13.1 kg, without any controller retuning. These experimental results are obtained using off-the-shelf components, for a 32 mm diameter, 300 mm stroke piston-type pneumatic actuator capable of developing forces of several hundreds of Newtons. Although this is a macro system (≈600 × 50 × 50 mm), the control strategy may be easily adapted to smaller ones.

This paper is organized as follows. The servopneumatic system model is presented in the next section. The section ‘Non-linear controller’ is dedicated to a presentation of the non-linear controller which is subsequently tested in the section ‘Experimental assessment of the control strategy’. Finally, the main conclusions drawn from this work are presented.

sec.title: Servopneumatic system model
sec.p: Figure 1 presents a schematic representation of the pneumatic servosystem (see Appendix 1 for a list of notation). Notice that although the use of a single five-orifice servovalve is more common in the literature (see, for instance, Drakunov et al.24 and Richer and Hurmuzlu26,33), considering two servovalves allows an extra degree of freedom that can be exploited to enhance the performance of the system, as will be discussed in the section ‘Force division block’. Moreover, by enforcing symmetric control actions, the use of two three-orifice servovalves becomes identical to the use of a single five-orifice one. Consequently, the system becomes more flexible using two servovalves.
Applying Newton’s second law to the system in Figure 1 results in the following equation
where Ffr and Fext are the friction and external forces, respectively, and

is the available pneumatic force with Fatm = PatmAh. No external forces are considered to act on the cylinder in this work so Fext = 0. The friction data of the actuator was obtained using the experimental procedure detailed in Falcão Carneiro and Gomes de Almeida34 and is presented in Figure 2.

caption.p: Experimental friction data (a) surface view,(b) Fatr− dx/dt plane and (c) Fatr − dx2/dt2 plane.

sec.p: The friction model is provided by an offline-trained neural network, denoted as FANN that maps the surface of Figure 2, and is defined by equation (3). The FANN network is a fully connected multilayer perceptron with three layers L1, L2 and L3. L1 has 10 tansig neurons (see equation (4)), L2 has six tansig neurons and L3 a linear neuron

The time evolution of pressures PA and PB can be obtained using the thermodynamic model of the air inside each chamber. As presented in Carneiro and Almeida35 this model can be derived from physics first principles and contains two differential equations with temperature and pressure as state variables. It is consequently difficult to handle mathematically and furthermore it requires a mass or temperature observer since these variables cannot be correctly measured during operation. Reduced-order models are consequently used in practice. Temperature is the natural state variable to eradicate since force and motion state directly depend on pressure (see equation (1)).

This work will use the results obtained in Carneiro and Almeida35 where a comparison study between several reduced-order models reported in the literature and several original ones was developed. The model given by equations (5) and (6) with n = 1.35 was selected as the best model in Carneiro and Almeida35 and will consequently be used in this work to describe the evolution of pressure inside each chamber. This model neglects the heat transfer that occurs when the air coming from the servovalves mixes with the air inside the cylinder chambers. However, it explicitly considers the heat transfer between the chambers’ air and the cylinder walls. Further details on this model can be found in Carneiro and Almeida.35 The value of the thermal conductance k0 was experimentally determined using the procedure presented in Carneiro and Almeida36

list-item.p: the variations of the temperature of the cylinder chambers with respect to ambient temperature Tamb are negligible;

the ambient pressure Patm, ambient temperature and source pressure only suffer small deviations from their nominal values. It is important to mention that the assumption of a constant supply pressure is consistent with common servopneumatic practice since an air accumulator is typically inserted in the circuit feeding line.

The IANN network has three fully connected layers with ten tansig, six tansig and one linear neuron, respectively. A detailed description of the procedures used to obtain experimental data and of the network training is beyond the scope of this paper and is provided in Carneiro and Almeida.38–40

caption.p: Block diagram of the closed-loop control of the servopneumatic system.

sec.title: Non-linear controller
sec.p:
The block diagram presented in Figure 4 describes the controller architecture developed in this work. Given a trajectory reference (
x
ref
,
x
·
ref
,
x
··
ref
) and the friction force estimate
F
^
fr
given by equation (3), the motion controller provides a pneumatic force reference Fpref. Since two servovalves are used, the force in each chamber can be independently imposed and consequently there are several combinations of force references in chambers A (FAref) and B (FBref) − see equation (10) − that satisfy a given Fpref. The choice on which combination to use is made by a force division block. The force division block used in this work provides force references so that pneumatic force saturation is avoided in both chambers. Full details of the force division block will be presented in the section ‘Force division block’. These references are then used by the force controllers to determine a desired mass flow. The value of the command input is finally provided by the IANN models.

Notice that the motion model is very uncertain since the moving mass and friction forces can widely change. This justifies the use of a robust motion controller. On the other hand, due to the work developed in Carneiro and Almeida35 it is assumed that the thermodynamic model is accurately known and therefore a more model-dependent control strategy will be used for force control.

sec.title: Motion control
sec.p: In this work a VSC was chosen for motion control. The VSC includes an adjustable thickness boundary layer φ around the switching surface σ in order to reduce chattering. Applying the classical VSC approach presented in Slotine and Li23 to system (1) using the sliding surface defined by equation (11), the control law defined by equation (12) results

with the moving mass estimate

where Mmin and Mmax are the minimum and maximum mass bounds of the system, respectively. The motion following error is defined by
and kvsc is the discontinuous component gain that must conform equation (15) so that attractiveness to the boundary layer is ensured23

In equation (15)

is the absolute maximum error of the friction force prediction and β is dependent on the uncertainty on the moving mass of the system

An interesting feature of the boundary layer thickness variation law used in this work (see equation (17)) is that it varies according to the approach angle θ of the system state to the sliding surface, as explained in detail in Carneiro and Almeida41

The sliding surface defined in equation (11) includes an integral action, leading to a maximum tracking error ε that is lower than the one obtained with a more conventional sliding surface that does not include it. In fact, using the procedure presented in Slotine and Li23 it can be shown that the value of ε using equation (11) is given by equation (18) while without integral action the value of ε is given by equation (19)
with e representing the Neper number.

sec.title: Force division block
sec.p: The use of two servovalves allows an extra degree of freedom that can be used to enhance the system performance. For instance, some researchers have used this degree of freedom to reduce energy consumption.42–44 The policy followed in this work is different and tries to maximize the force range of the cylinder by avoiding force saturation of the cylinder chambers. Notice that the available pneumatic force inside a pneumatic cylinder chamber is dependent not only on the maximum available pressure but also on the piston velocity. In fact, at steady state conditions, equation (6) can be written as
for chamber A and as

for chamber B. Equations (20) and (21) show that for a given mass flow, the available pneumatic force decreases with an increase in velocity. This effect cannot nevertheless be included in a force division policy since the mass flow itself depends on the working pressure. Consequently, it is only possible to take into account the effect of the maximum positive and negative available pneumatic forces
F

caption.p: Range of pneumatic forces in each cylinder chamber.

sec.p: For positive pneumatic force references, define ΔA as the fraction of the total force Fpref developed by chamber A (FAref) around the equilibrium force FA0 = PA0AA (see Figure 5)
For negative force references, define ΔB as the fraction of the total force Fpref developed by chamber B (FBref) around the equilibrium force FB0 = PB0AB (see Figure 5)
Theorems 1 and 2 provide the conditions that avoid force saturation in both chambers for positive and negative force references, respectively.

Theorem 1. For Fpref≥ 0, define FAref and FBref around the equilibrium forces FA0 and FB0 as indicated in equation (26) and (27), respectively. If ΔA is defined as in equation (28) with Δ1 as defined as in equation (29), then propositions (30) and (31) hold and force saturation does not occur in the cylinder chambers

Theorem 2. For Fpref < 0, define FAref and FBref around the equilibrium forces FA0 and FB0 as indicated in equation (34) and equation (35), respectively. If ΔB is defined as in equation (36) with Δ2 defined as in equation (37) then propositions (38) and (39) hold

. In this situation, equation (34) reduces to equation (40) and equation (35) to equation (41). Consequently, inequalities (38) and (39) are satisfied and no saturation occurs in chamber A or B for negative pneumatic force references

The force references for chambers A and B are consequently defined by equation (26) and equation (27), respectively, when Fpref≥0, and by equation (34) and equation (35), respectively, when Fpref<0. Equilibrium pressures PA0 and PB0 were calculated in order to fulfill two conditions: first, symmetry around the pressure range average value (P = 4×105 Pa), with Ps = 7×105 Pa; and second, static force equilibrium. The final values obtained were PA0 = 3.78×105 Pa and PB0=4.22×105 Pa.

sec.title: Force controller
sec.p: Each chamber force controller has two control loops as presented in Figure 6. The inner loop contains a non-linear state feedback controller23 that uses measured values of PA and PB in order to linearize the force dynamics. Although this is a very highly model-dependent control law, it is considered that the thermodynamic model is accurately known, as previously explained, so model dependence does not have any negative implications on the present study. The control laws were synthesized using the pressure dynamic model given by equations (5) and (6), leading to equations (46) and (47). The outer loop is based on a proportional control action. Feed forward of the filtered derivative of the force reference was used in order to increase the bandwidth of the closed-loop force dynamics. Equations (42) to (47) present the final control laws obtained.
With
where VAd and VBd represent the dead volumes of chamber A and B, respectively, and TA and TB are calculated using equation (5).

sec.title: Experimental assessment of the control strategy
Experimental setup
sec.p: The experimental setup used in this work includes two subsystems: the data acquisition and control hardware/software; and the electropneumatic components, presented in Figure 7. The data acquisition and control system consist of a PC with data acquisition boards and all the hardware/software needed for signal processing. The electropneumatic system includes an air treatment unit, two servovalves, a pneumatic actuator driving the carriage of a monorail guideway, two pressure transducers and a digital encoder for position measurements, integrated in the guidance system, with a resolution of 5 µm. The pneumatic actuator was manufactured by Asco-Joucomatic (ASCO Numatics GmbH, Sankt Augustin, Germany) and has a usable stroke length of 280 mm, a piston diameter φ = 32 mm and a rod diameter φh = 16 mm. Both servovalves were manufactured by Festo (MPYE-5-1/8-HF-010-B, Festo AG & Co., Berkheim, Germany), were used as three-orifice valves with a nominal mass flow of 700 SLPM. The mass of the system can be changed from 2.69 to 13.1 kg by stacking metal sheets on the carriage.

caption.p: Picture of the servopneumatic experimental setup.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p:
The developed controller was tested in the experimental setup in order to evaluate its performance in several positioning tasks (for trajectory following tasks please see Falcão Carneiro and Gomes de Almeida45). Table 1 presents the controller parameters, all of which were experimentally tuned with the exception of the uncertainties regarding friction model |efr|max (obtained using the results presented in Falcão Carneiro and Gomes de Almeida34), payload
M
^
and its variation β (defined in the previous section).

In order to establish the performance of the controller, several micro positioning tasks were tested with three different loads: M = Mmin = 2.69 kg, M = Mmed = 5.9 kg and M = Mmax = 13.1 kg. The controller parameters were experimentally tuned for Mmed and held constant during the trials. The position reference signal was a 5 µm increasing and decreasing staircase with a total range of 100 µm (see Figures 8 to 10). It can be noticed that very accurate results are obtained. Indeed, regarding steady state errors, an error below 5 µm, corresponding to a zero control error, is obtained in all the trials. Regarding the dynamic response, notice that for increasing position references a positive (5 µm) or zero error is obtained whereas for decreasing references a negative (−5 µm) or zero error is found. This indicates that there is an overshoot in some of the steps. This overshoot cannot, however, be corrected by the controller due to the encoder resolution limitation. It should also be noted that these results are obtained with very high load variations (Mmax≈5×Mmin), demonstrating the high robustness to parametric variation of the control architecture presented in this work. Furthermore, the controller performance is apparently being limited by the encoder resolution and consequently future work will include an encoder with better resolution.
Notice that due to space limitations only staircases starting at x = 0 mm are shown. Similar results were nevertheless obtained for staircases starting anywhere in the range x[–140,140] mm.

One of the advantages of the device presented in this work is that not only micro but also macro movements are achieved with low positioning errors, regardless of the payload. To illustrate this, additional experiments were performed using acceleration, velocity and position references in order to generate smoothed steps (S-shaped curves) as exemplified in Figure 11.

caption.p: S-shaped position curves: position, velocity, acceleration and its derivative.

sec.p: Figures 12 to 14 present the position, error absolute value (using a logarithmic scale) and control action results obtained with Mmin,Mmed and Mmax with position references ranging from xref = −0.014 m to xref = 0.014 m. A steady state error less than 5 µm can be seen in all trials, with a fast response corresponding to settling times (|e|≤5 µm) below 1.6 s. It should be noted that the algorithm used to generate the reference values relies on numerical integration of the derivative of acceleration, acceleration and velocity and consequently the steady state position references may not be an integer multiple of 5 µm, the encoder resolution. These references are unreachable since the controller can only perceive 5 µm position changes. In these situations, the piston position oscillates between the upper and lower 5 µm rounded values next to the position reference. An example of this situation can be seen in Figure 15, an expanded representation of Figure 12 for 20 < t < 25 s. The position reference is situated between 19.995 and 20.000 mm and consequently the piston position oscillates between these two values. As a counterexample of this situation, Figure 16 presents the static error for an achievable position reference, namely the piston central position. As can be seen in this graph, zero error is obtained.

caption.p: Expanded plot of Figure 12 for 20<t<25 s.
Expanded plot of Figure 12 for 8<t<11 s.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This paper presented a micro–macro motion pneumatic device capable of achieving positioning errors of ±5 µm anywhere in a 280 mm stroke length. The positioning error is actually being limited by the encoder resolution (5 µm), so from a control perspective zero steady state error is obtained. These results are obtained with any mass ranging from 2.69 to 13.1 kg and without performing any controller retuning. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, these results outperform any previously published work on pneumatic systems control employing off-the-shelf components. Leveraging on pneumatic systems intrinsic proprieties like low cost or the absence of thermic or magnetic fields emission, it is believed that this work may contribute to the use of pneumatic systems in micro–macro positioning tasks that are conventionally performed using PZT, electrical motors or hybrid actuation systems.
